user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_BSP_EndTest:
```c
void UT_BSP_EndTest(const UtAssert_TestCounter_t *TestCounters)
{
    char Message[128];

    /*
     * Only output a "summary" if there is more than one test Segment.
     * Otherwise it is a duplicate of the report already given.
     */
    if (TestCounters->TestSegmentCount > 1)
    {
        UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport("SUMMARY", TestCounters);
    }

    snprintf(Message, sizeof(Message), "COMPLETE: %u tests Segment(s) executed\n\n",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->TestSegmentCount);

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(Message, strlen(Message));
    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    if ((TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE] > 0) ||
        (TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF] > 0) || (TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF] > 0))
    {
        OS_BSP_SetExitCode(OS_ERROR);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_BSP_SetExitCode(OS_SUCCESS);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(Message, strlen(Message));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: snprintf(Message, sizeof(Message), ...) guarantees NUL-termination for the buffer (sizeof(Message) == 128 > 0), so strlen(Message) will only access bytes within Message and not read beyond its bounds. A specific violation scenario would be if Message were not NUL-terminated (for example if Message were filled by a function that does not guarantee termination when truncated, such as strncpy used without manual termination, or if the buffer size passed to snprintf were zero or incorrect). In that case, strlen(Message) could read past the end of the array and violate Rule 21.17.
